newsitem.title: UK: LME metals retreat by end after attack on upside.
newsitem.headline: LME metals retreat by end after attack on upside.

text.p: LME metals prices took a breath on Thursday afternoon, drifting back after several days of heated rises.
Many in the complex still have upside potential, but need to consolidate before resuming the upward path, analysts said.
"Short term it has done enough. The whole complex needs to pause," said analyst William Adams of broker Rudolf Wolff.

Metals marched higher in the morning, with nickel and tin scoring four-month highs, zinc pushing to a new 23-month peak, lead at its strongest for two months and aluminium matching an eight-month high.
Copper ran up to $2,295 on commission house buying, but when it failed to surmount the psychological $2,300 level, profit-taking came in, traders said.
The move lower took copper away from the next major target for the market, the November 28 high of $2,313.
Lending contributed to the softer tone and prices eased further in the afternoon, ending the kerb at $2,248, down $14.
The premium of cash over three months flared to $185/90 in the morning, but came in about $10 by the close.
Aluminium failed for the third time to breach $1,625, matching Monday's and Tuesday's peaks.
It needs to close above $1,123/4 to further spice up the technical picture and break above a two-year sideways pattern.
Lead broke through the key $723 level on its way to peaking at $730, but like the others, retreated to close the kerb at $710, down $6.
Nickel earlier knocked down an important Elliott Wave chartpoint at $7,450 on its way to $7,490, but drifted back to finish at $7,380, off $30.
Tin joined the others, rising to $6,130 before sliding back to close $90 lower at $5,985.
Alloy was little changed at $1,510/12 from $1,508/10.
--Eric Onstad, London Newsroom +44 171 542 8065
Call option buying has been helping keep aluminium buoyant, Wolff's Adams said.
The market needs a rest to calm its overbought status while producer selling is expected to trim the upside, traders said.
By the end of the day, aluminium had drifted back to $1,507, off $10.
Zinc, which along with lead was earlier boosted by fund short-covering, carved out a fresh high at $1,133. It drifted back with the others, finishing the day $2 down at $1,120.
Chartists say it needs a spell of consolidation after soaring by more than 10 percent this week.
